newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico union boss attacks economic pact talks.
newsitem.headline: Mexico union boss attacks economic pact talks.

text.p: Fidel Velazquez, the powerful leader of the pro-government Mexican Workers Confederation (CTM), has attacked the annual economic pact negotiation with the government, newspapers reported Tuesday.
Velazquez has been increasingly critical of the government's free-market policies.

He told reporters at his weekly news conference Monday that the current Alliance for Economic Recovery (ARE), the government's economic program negotiated with business and labour last year, had been "left behind" by events.
Velazquez said the CTM would not sign another economic pact if it meant the government would raise prices and hold down wages.
He said the government should agree to pay "remunerative wages" to workers, preferably using a index-linked system to guarantee they would not suffer a loss of purchasing power.
Talks on a new economic pact are due to start soon. The government has repeatedly refused to consider index-linking wages because of its inflationary impact.
